over a time interval sufficiently long to reliably estimate

and which is far enough in advance to be useful. We denote the period over which values of

are averaged the “assessment interval”. Thus, in Fig. 3a, c the proxies
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\langle \lambda _t^ \ast \rangle$$\end{document}

are calculated with a 12-week assessment window ending 3 months prior to onset (here defined by λ* > 1) and beginning with data 6 months prior (Methods). Figure 3c shows the performance measured by the Pearson correlation between
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\langle \lambda _t^ \ast \rangle$$\end{document}

λ
t
*
⟩
and the observed outbreak magnitude. It is 0.71 ( p = 6 × 10 −4). Importantly, these results are robust to how the assessment interval is selected, how the magnitude of an outbreak is defined, and how the predictor is constructed (see Supplementary Figs. 1 and 2). This robustness is highlighted in Fig. 3b, d with an assessment interval that is arbitrarily fixed by calendar day. The correlation between the predictors
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\langle \lambda _t^ \ast \rangle$$\end{document}

and the outbreak magnitudes is 0.76, with p = 5 × 10 −5.
